Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I was on the train, heading across the state to join my family for the festival. The air was thick with the scent of marigolds and incense, and my mother’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me how important it was to be present for every ritual. My phone buzzed. It was a new client, calling during my journey. He sounded anxious, asking for basic tips on operating his new machine. I could hear the uncertainty in his voice, and I knew my job was to guide him, to make sure he felt supported. But the train was about to enter a tunnel, and soon I’d lose signal. My family expected me to arrive on time, to help with the preparations, to show my devotion. My client expected clear, patient guidance. I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between the duty to my faith and the responsibility to my work. The festival was only once a year, but so was a client’s first impression. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I would have to let down.
